TextEquiv.Unicode: king, and lone, and charitie, and good
will, and fellowshippe let there be be
twixt man and wife. For to that end
the woman was take out of the mans
bodie, that the husband should cherish
(his wife) his owne bodie. And for that
cause the Apostle saith: So must hus
bandes love their wives, even as their
owne bodies. He that loveth his wife
doeth love himselfe. For no man at
anie time hath hated his owne flesh,
but loveth and cherisheth it, as the
Lorde doth the Church. What may
be said to that moreover, that the Apo
stle in the very same place hath made
the sonne of God and the holy Church
an example for married folkes to fol
lowe in keeping of wedlocke requiring
at the husbands hand to love his wife,
even as Christ hath loved the Church:
and of the wife to reverence her hus
bande and to love him againe, as the
Church doth Christ? Than which ex
ample, there is none in the world more
holy and effectual. For there is no love
greater, tha the love of Christ toward
his Church. Neither is there any love
more chast, tha that which the Church
doth beare to Christ.
It is therfore required at the hands
of wedded ates, mutually to beare
most ardent and holie love the one to
the other. Let them use all things in
common: let them be partakers both
of the same propertie, and the same
adversitie. Let them both drawe un
der one yoke, and beare betwixt them
one an others burden. Briefely, let
them twaine bee the members of one
and the very same bodie. I have more
at large set downe these offices of man
and wife, in my treatise which is cal
ed the Institution of Christian Ma
trimonie.
Lastly, let them bring up their chil
dren in holy discipline, and the feare of

king, and lone, and charitie, and good will, and fellowshippe let there be be twixt man and wife. For to that end the woman was take out of the mans bodie, that the husband should cherish (his wife) his owne bodie. And for that cause the Apostle saith: So must hus bandes love their wives, even as their owne bodies. He that loveth his wife doeth love himselfe. For no man at anie time hath hated his owne flesh, but loveth and cherisheth it, as the Lorde doth the Church. What may be said to that moreover, that the Apo stle in the very same place hath made the sonne of God and the holy Church an example for married folkes to fol lowe in keeping of wedlocke requiring at the husbands hand to love his wife, even as Christ hath loved the Church: and of the wife to reverence her hus bande and to love him againe, as the Church doth Christ? Than which ex ample, there is none in the world more holy and effectual. For there is no love greater, tha the love of Christ toward his Church. Neither is there any love more chast, tha that which the Church doth beare to Christ. It is therfore required at the hands of wedded ates, mutually to beare most ardent and holie love the one to the other. Let them use all things in common: let them be partakers both of the same propertie, and the same adversitie. Let them both drawe un der one yoke, and beare betwixt them one an others burden. Briefely, let them twaine bee the members of one and the very same bodie. I have more at large set downe these offices of man and wife, in my treatise which is cal ed the Institution of Christian Ma trimonie. Lastly, let them bring up their chil dren in holy discipline, and the feare of
God, to the health of their owne house
and the whole common weale. Paule
saieth: I would have the younger wo
men marrie, to get children & to go
verne the house, for that is honest and
acceptable before God. But touch
ing the bringing up of children, I have
alreadie spoken in the fift Sermon of
this Decade. Now the very begetting
of children alone is verie profitable
both to everie private or particular
house, and also to the common weale:
for heere I will not stand to shew that
the honour and glorie of God, is verie
greatly augmented, if children be not
onely begotten, but also brought up in
the feare of god, and knowledge of his
worde. Hierocles saith: I confesse that
marriage is profitable: especially be
cause it bringeth children forth, which
is in deede a goodly fruit, for they, be
ing of our verie bloud, doe while wee
are in health aide us in all our affaires:
and in old age when yeares come upo
us, they succour us well with all that
they may: they are familier compa
nions of our joy in prosperitie, and in
adversitie are our partners, in sorrow
ing with us, for our heavie mishappes.
And so foorth. Antipater also sayeth:
Man which is indued with a civill dis
position to maintaine societie, must
augment his country and common
wealth with increase of children: for
cities could not have beene preserved
by any meanes at all, unlesse the head
men of everie citie, and the sonnes of
noble Gentlemen, seeing their aunce
tours wither and fall away like goodly
leaves of a faire tree, had married in
time convenient, and lefte behinde
them children as worthie pleantes to
succeede in their Countrie, thereby
to make it flourish for ever, dooing
their best so farre as they coulde, to
keepe it from the assaultes and con

God, to the health of their owne house and the whole common weale. Paule saieth: I would have the younger wo men marrie, to get children & to go verne the house, for that is honest and acceptable before God. But touch ing the bringing up of children, I have alreadie spoken in the fift Sermon of this Decade. Now the very begetting of children alone is verie profitable both to everie private or particular house, and also to the common weale: for heere I will not stand to shew that the honour and glorie of God, is verie greatly augmented, if children be not onely begotten, but also brought up in the feare of god, and knowledge of his worde. Hierocles saith: I confesse that marriage is profitable: especially be cause it bringeth children forth, which is in deede a goodly fruit, for they, be ing of our verie bloud, doe while wee are in health aide us in all our affaires: and in old age when yeares come upo us, they succour us well with all that they may: they are familier compa nions of our joy in prosperitie, and in adversitie are our partners, in sorrow ing with us, for our heavie mishappes. And so foorth. Antipater also sayeth: Man which is indued with a civill dis position to maintaine societie, must augment his country and common wealth with increase of children: for cities could not have beene preserved by any meanes at all, unlesse the head men of everie citie, and the sonnes of noble Gentlemen, seeing their aunce tours wither and fall away like goodly leaves of a faire tree, had married in time convenient, and lefte behinde them children as worthie pleantes to succeede in their Countrie, thereby to make it flourish for ever, dooing their best so farre as they coulde, to keepe it from the assaultes and con
